desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 12 - 27 m tall, trunk diameter 30 cm - 0.6 m. Crown cylindrical to irregular, with a few large, upright branches.

part.partText: gray or yellowish brown, thin, and smooth on young trees, becoming light brown and furrowed with scaly ridges.

stout, brown or gray, smooth or hairy, lenticels prominent, epidermis peeling or flaking (except on current year’s growth). Leaf scars triangular, with 3 bundle scars each. Pith orange, star-shaped in cross-section.
reddish brown, egg-shaped, pointed, resinous; terminal bud 1.5 - 2 cm long.

alternate, with 6 - 10 cm long, smooth or sparsely hairy, not flattened leafstalks; green above, paler beneath, 8 - 25 cm long, 6 - 20 cm wide, broadly egg-shaped, base rounded or heart-shaped, tip rounded or bluntly pointed, margins blunt-toothed, densely white-woolly when young, becoming smooth with age (undersides may remain hairy, especially along major veins).

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy-bracted, stiff catkins; male catkins long-stalked, 3 - 10 cm long, thick, anthers red; female catkins long-stalked, few-flowered, 3 - 15 cm long, slender; wind-pollinated.
a 2 - 3 valved capsule; borne in drooping catkins 6 - 15 cm long; reddish brown, egg-shaped, seeds light brown with cottony hairs attached; wind-dispersed.

similarSpecies.comments: Populus heterophylla is best distinguished from other Populus species (except P. balsamifera) by having essentially round, not flat, leafstalks. It is distinguished from P. balsamifera by having bluntly pointed leaves with woolly undersides (especially along major veins).

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Typical of swamps and low woods. It is very rare in the Chicago Region, but can be found in the swampy woodlands of the Kankakee River valley. In 1989 it was discovered at the Momence wetlands in Kankakee County, growing in a backwater area where there is standing water much of the year.

notes.comments: The wood of Populus heterophylla is used for pulp, fuel, and interior finishing. Populus species as a whole are subject to many diseases and insect pests, such as canker and tent caterpillars, which often kill the tree or make it unattractive. These risks, in conjunction with a water-hungry root system, have made Populus species less desirable for landscape use.

etymology.comments: Populus is the Latin word for poplar. Heterophylla means “diversely leaved.”
